ik ben het er niet mee eens dat er een zeer extreme attractie gebouwd word, 
zoiets hoort in six flax, maar niet in de Efteling.
Waarom niet gewoon verder met hartenhof en de attractie die bedoeld was 
voor pardoes en pardijntje?﻿
top_comment.author: Albie lovesherperry

comments.text:
Hartenhof zal later gebouwd worden, en ik vind zelf dat Baron 1898 een hele 
goede keuze is van de Efteling. Als je namelijk kijkt naar andere dive 
coasters als Sheikra en Griffon zal deze dive coaster redelijk klein 
worden. En een hier een citaat van de directeur van de Efteling heeft 
gezegd: ''Als we alles bij het oude hadden gelaten, had het park nu niet 
meer bestaan''. Hier bedoeld hij mee dat ze voor de jongeren die ze nu 
vooral willen aantrekken door steeds nieuwe en spannendere dingen gaan 
bouwen. En nog een rede: Mensen dachten er precies zo over als jij toen de 
Python gebouwd werd... Dus ik vind het een hele goede keuze van de +Efteling
...
comments.author: Tycho den Hartog

captions.text: We're hoping for favourable weather conditions this winter, in order to meet our schedule.
When you see the deep mineshaft taking shape and actually enter the ground...
...which is an entirely different dimension...
...it begins to feel like a reality.
This series takes you on a journey through the development...
...and creation of Efteling's latest spectacular attraction.
There's a lot happening on the Baron 1898 construction site...
where a massive tunnel is being excavated, groundwork is also taking place...
...and the first contours of the terminal building are becoming visible.
How do you go about building a mining operation?
And why is a 10-metre deep mineshaft being dug?
This is 'The Making of: Baron 1898'.
Now that the first design drawings have been presented and we know that Baron 1898 has a mining theme...
...the construction work at Efteling goes into full flow.
A visually important aspect of the new attraction is its unique terminal.
The terminal building is crucial to the attraction as a whole.
As well as containing the rollercoaster ride, it is also the grand entrance to the attraction.
It is the basis of the story and the look and feel of the attraction.
It's the key to the entire mining theme and you will later explore all sections of the building as a miner.
The terminal was traditionally a collection point for miners and service staff.
It contained lift operators who lowered miners down into the mineshaft and brought them back up again.
It was the main transportation hub for the miners.
The attraction comprises a number of buildings, forming a small mining operation.
A kind of factory with various special rooms and sections.
We tried to avoid building a large, open room or hall...
...and therefore decided to give the building as much variation as possible, in height, depth and appearance.
This creates the impression of a building complex, rather than a single building.
'Five to go up'
The materials chosen were mainly bricks and steel.
Technical drawings were made for each steel beam, bulkhead and brace, and everything else that you see.
Each item was carefully designed and drawn before being manufactured and numbered...
...as part of the overall construction package waiting to be assembled.
When that time comes, you are confronted with a jigsaw puzzle of steel girders, which must be pieced together before building can commence.
When you see that it all fits together and is about to become a reality..
...it gives you goosebumps and you realise there's no turning back now.
You can only look ahead.
The first section of the construction work - the steel frame - is complete.
The next step is the construction of the brickwork, for which a whole team of bricklayers is ready to begin...
...in order to make the building weatherproof as quickly as possible.
We are also still busy working on the mineshaft, which is needed for the ride's rapid descent.
The shaft is 40 metres long, eight metres wide and 10 metres deep.
It is something completely new and the building process is quite impressive.
Standard building methods do not apply here, due to the relatively small size of the construction site.
We needed to devise special techniques to execute the tunnelling work.
We use the earth, mix it with mortar and use this to make the walls.
We are working to a very tight construction schedule.
We started to prepare the site in August and we will carry on working...
...through a season with a high probability of frost.
The pressure on the construction schedule is therefore quite high.
So we're hoping for favourable weather conditions this winter and that everything goes to plan and is on time.
We've made a good start but there's still a long way to go.
Alongside the construction work on the terminal building, a new walking path is also being laid.
The path crosses a unique, iron bridge, which forms an important part of the attraction's overall appearance.
Another special moment is also taking place on the construction site...
...the very first sections of track for the terminal building are about to be delivered to Efteling.
Baron 1898 is really beginning to take shape.
Subscribe and stay on the lookout for further episodes of 'The Making-of: Baron 1898'.
